content:
🔬 Pixelator: Molecular Pixelation Spatial Proteomics

Map Protein Networks at Single-Cell Resolution

Molecular Pixelation is a revolutionary technology that combines antibody-based detection with sequencing to reveal spatial protein organization and protein-protein interactions within individual cells. Unlike traditional proteomics that averages across millions of cells, Molecular Pixelation preserves the spatial context of protein networks, uncovering cell-to-cell variability and rare cellular states.

🎯 What This Pipeline Does

The Pixelator pipeline processes raw sequencing data from Molecular Pixelation experiments through a comprehensive analysis workflow:

  • 📊 Quality Control: Rigorous QC of sequencing reads to ensure data quality

  • 🧬 Amplicon Processing: Assembly and validation of molecular barcodes

  • 🏷️ Marker Assignment: Maps antibody markers to their targets with high precision

  • ✅ Error Correction: Advanced algorithms to minimize sequencing and PCR errors

  • 🕸️ Graph Generation: Creates cellular protein networks showing spatial relationships

  • 🧮 Spatial Analysis: Quantifies protein colocalization and proximity patterns

  • 🎨 3D Visualization: Generates interactive 3D graph layouts of protein networks

  • 📈 Statistical Reports: Comprehensive analysis reports with quality metrics

🔬 Experimental Designs Supported

MPX (Molecular Pixelation) Assays

  • 🎯 Application: Spatial proteomics with subcellular resolution

  • 🧬 Technology: Antibody-DNA conjugates on solid phase

  • 📊 Output: Protein abundance maps with spatial coordinates

  • ✅ Best for: Mapping protein distribution patterns in single cells

PNA (Proximity Network Assay)

  • 🎯 Application: Protein-protein interaction networks

  • 🧬 Technology: Proximity-based ligation of antibody markers

  • 📊 Output: Interaction graphs showing direct protein relationships

  • ✅ Best for: Discovering protein complexes and signaling networks

📋 Required Inputs

1. Sample Sheet (CSV Format)

Create a samplesheet describing your Molecular Pixelation experiment:

sample,fastq_1,fastq_2,panel,panel_name,panel_version
control_1,control_R1.fastq.gz,control_R2.fastq.gz,panel.txt,immune_panel,v1
treatment_1,treat_R1.fastq.gz,treat_R2.fastq.gz,panel.txt,immune_panel,v1

Column Descriptions:

  • sample: Unique identifier for each sample

  • fastq_1: Path or URL to Read 1 FASTQ file (contains barcodes)

  • fastq_2: Path or URL to Read 2 FASTQ file (contains UMIs)

  • panel: Path to antibody panel specification file

  • panel_name: Descriptive name for the antibody panel used

  • panel_version: Version identifier for reproducibility

2. Antibody Panel File

Defines the antibody markers used in your experiment with their sequences. Provided by Pixelgen Technologies or custom designed for your targets.

3. Data Type Selection

Specify whether your experiment uses:

  • MPX: Standard Molecular Pixelation protocol

  • PNA: Proximity Network Assay protocol

📊 Analysis Outputs

Processed Data Files (PXL Format)

  • 📦 PXL Files: Pixelator's native format containing all cellular data

  • 🧬 Count Matrices: Protein expression per cell

  • 🕸️ Graph Data: Cellular protein network structures

  • 📍 Spatial Coordinates: Protein localization information

Quality Control Reports

  • 📈 MultiQC Report: Comprehensive quality metrics across all samples

  • 📊 Read Statistics: Sequencing depth and barcode quality

  • 🎯 Marker Detection: Antibody-specific performance metrics

  • 🧮 Cell Counts: Number of cells detected per sample

Visualization Files

  • 🎨 3D Graph Layouts: Interactive protein network visualizations

  • 📍 Spatial Maps: Protein distribution heatmaps

  • 🔗 Colocalization Plots: Protein-protein proximity analysis

  • 📊 Summary Plots: Per-sample and per-marker statistics

Statistical Analysis

  • 🧮 Polarization Scores: Asymmetric protein distributions within cells

  • 🔬 Colocalization Metrics: Statistical significance of protein proximity

  • 📈 Marker Abundance: Quantitative protein levels per cell

  • 🕸️ Network Statistics: Graph connectivity and topology metrics

🧪 Scientific Applications

This technology is ideal for research in:

  • 🦠 Immunology: Map immune receptor organization and signaling complexes

  • 🧬 Cancer Biology: Discover oncogenic protein networks and drug resistance mechanisms

  • 🧠 Neuroscience: Study synaptic protein organization and neuronal signaling

  • 💊 Drug Discovery: Identify therapeutic targets within protein complexes

  • 🔬 Cell Biology: Understand organelle proteomes and cellular compartmentation

  • 🧫 Stem Cell Research: Track protein network changes during differentiation

  • 🔥 Inflammation: Characterize inflammatory signaling cascades

  • 🌟 Rare Cell Types: Profile protein networks in rare cellular populations

🎯 Key Advantages Over Traditional Proteomics

  • 🔍 Single-Cell Resolution: No averaging across cell populations

  • 📍 Spatial Context: Preserves protein localization information

  • 🕸️ Interaction Networks: Direct measurement of protein-protein relationships

  • 🎯 Targeted Sensitivity: Antibody-based detection with high specificity

  • 💰 Cost-Effective: NGS-based approach scalable to many cells

  • 🧬 Complementary to scRNA-seq: Protein validation of transcript predictions

⚙️ Technical Specifications

Computational Requirements:

  • Memory: Minimum 32GB RAM, 64GB recommended for large experiments

  • Storage: 50-100GB per sample depending on sequencing depth

  • Runtime: 2-6 hours per sample on LARGE compute nodes

Data Requirements:

  • Sequencing Depth: Typically 50,000-200,000 reads per cell

  • Read Format: Paired-end Illumina sequencing

  • Panel Size: 40-150 antibody markers typical

📚 Scientific Background

Molecular Pixelation was developed based on the principle that proteins found in close proximity are likely to interact functionally. The technology uses antibody-DNA conjugates and proximity ligation to create molecular barcodes that encode both protein identity and spatial relationships. By sequencing these barcodes and reconstructing the spatial graph, researchers can map the protein interaction landscape of single cells.

The approach was published in Nature Methods (2024) and represents a breakthrough in spatial proteomics, enabling researchers to see protein organization patterns that were previously invisible to traditional mass spectrometry or Western blot approaches.

🛠️ Pipeline Workflow

For MPX Data:

  1. Amplicon building from raw reads

  2. Read quality control and filtering

  3. Marker assignment to antibodies

  4. Error correction (sequencing and PCR)

  5. Graph component computation

  6. Cell annotation and filtering

  7. Polarization and colocalization analysis

  8. 3D graph layout generation

  9. Report generation

For PNA Data:

  1. Quality control of reads

  2. Amplicon building

  3. Marker-based grouping

  4. Molecule derivation

  5. Graph component computation

  6. Cell graph denoising

  7. Spatial analysis

  8. 3D graph layout generation

  9. Report generation

💡 Tips for Success

  • Panel Design: Choose antibodies targeting proteins with known interactions

  • Sequencing Depth: Higher depth improves graph connectivity and protein detection

  • Quality Control: Review MultiQC reports to identify problematic samples early

  • Biological Replicates: Include replicates to distinguish true biology from technical variation

  • Positive Controls: Use well-characterized cell types to validate marker performance

📖 Citation and Documentation

When using this pipeline, please cite:

  • Technology: Molecular Pixelation publication in Nature Methods (2024)
